div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: RHODES SCHOLAR ON OXFORD.
div.p: Mr. C. F. Tucker Brooke, the writer of the following notes on Oxford, is the first Rhodes Scholar appointed from West Virginia. He went over in 1904. He received the degree of A.B. from the University of West Virginia in 1901, and A.M. from the same place in 1902. He was a Fellow in German at the University of Chicago in 190e-04, and was awarded a first-class in the final examinations for the Oxford B.A. degree in the honour school of English language and literature last June, and this year will receive the degree of Bachelor of Letters. The article appears in the New York "Independent."

"During the coming summer there will return to the United States thirty five of her citizens, the survivors of the thirty-seven who,

in October, 1904, came into residence at Oxford as the first of the American Rhodes scholars," says Mr. Brooke. "It is now more than two years and a half since the majority of them, each from different State and totally unacquainted, sailed from Boston on the Cunarder 'Ivernia,' with visiting cards pinned to their coats to assist in their identification, and a great fellow-feeling in their hearts at being companions in the unknown life before them.

"The first separation came nine days later when a special boat-train from Liverpool put them out into one of Oxford's characteristically foggy nights, some to seek their respective colleges, rising grey and medieval in the dimness, with massive closed gates and iron barred windows, the more foresighted to bed at the hotels.

"During the first term Oxford was a great mystery and all-engrossing ; new experiences were continually arising, new conditions everyday unfolding themselves, to which the newcomer must adapt himself if he was to enter genuinely and as an active entity into the life about him. And now, on the eve of departure, after as long and intimate acquaintance as any good American could desire, Oxford remains equally a mystery, though 'scouts' and proctors, bumping races, 'schools,' and Gothic architecture are taken as matters of course, and life goes on as smoothly and naturally as in any American college.

"Nothing approaching a definite report of the scholastic career of the Rhodes scholars will be possible till the close of the present University year, as it has been only in isolated, and somewhat exceptional cases that the all-deciding final examinations have been taken before the expiration of the usual three years. It may, however, be said pretty confidently that such results as so far have transpired have rather exceeded than fallen short of anticipation ; that the initial distaste of the American students for the unfamiliar and--at least superficially--rigid Oxford methods has in great measure or wholly disappeared on better acquaintance, and that Oxford sentiment as a whole, tutorial and undergraduate, has regarded the infusion of purely American modes and ideals of study with a kindliness which in so conservative a community only a very bold prophet would have predicted.

"In the field of athletics the position of the Americans is more easily estimated, for the standard of what is to be expected of them in this same line seems, after a great deal of oscillation, to have reached a sane--and, one may hope, a permanent--equilibrium. The overemphasis of the athletic clause of the Rhodes will by the newspapers on both sides of the water, together with the rather too suspicious débout in Oxford sport--when at the freshmen's field day in their first term American Rhodes scholars won over two-thirds of the events--gave rise to some unfortunate misconceptions. All such misunderstandings have now entirely disappeared, and Oxford will no more expect of every member of succeeding generations of Rhodes scholars transcendent athletic prowess than it will require of each individual extraordinary scholarship or peculiar moral, social or political qualifications..... The Americans have taken readily to all the English outdoor sports except cricket. They can't obtain the proper regard for it for some reason. But they have given to the delighted aboriginal small boy the great American game of baseball, and their coolness on cricket is forgiven them."

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: Cattle plague has appeared between Tomat and Sofi in Kassala Province. It is believed to have been imported from the Erythrea.

div.head: Cotton at Tokar
div.p: Total sales of cotton at Tokar up to the end of June this year, have amounted to 65,955 kantars, against 37,956 kantars for the corresponding period last year. Prices have ranged this year between 75 and 94 piasters per kantar.

div.head: A Resourceful Cyclist
div.p: The "Daily Mail'' reports that a cyclist, overtaken by the dark and being without a lamp, evaded infringement of the law by picking up from the road an empty whisky bottle and filling it with fireflies. We are doubtful whether to congratulate the cyclist on having been so lucky as to find a bottle, cork, and fireflies together, or to marvel at the credulity of our contemporary.

div.head: Egyptian Company Motlose

div.head: Moslem Brotherhood
div.p: The prefecture of police has granted an authorisation to the Society of Moslems in Paris, which has been formed under the name of the "Brotherhood of Islam." Its programme states that Islam is a great international family, and that all Moslems are brothers. A community of sentiment and faith, it says, draws them together, and binds them to love and help one another, and it is with the view of furthering this ohjeet that the society has been formed.

div.head: Rains at Atbara
div.p: A telegram from Khartoum announces that more heavy rains have fallen at Atbara, and have destroyed the locality. The houses and shops are inundated, and the native and European inhabitants are flying into the country. Provisions have been sent to the victims. Two other telégrams announce that the Greek merchants have had their goods severely damaged. They are in the desert at present and the situation is very bad. It is reported that a subscription will be opened in Egypt for the Greek victims.

div.head: The Cotton Worm
div.p: The crusade against the above pest continues, and we are glad to report still further progress in the extermination. The figures for the week ending 7th Aug. are as follows:

The provinces of Assiout, Beni-Sonef, Fayoum, Ghiza, Minia and Kena remain immune. In Behera 16,697 feddans in 208 villages were infected and 16,647 cleared. In Dakahlieh 300 feddans in 52 villages were infected and cleared. In Gharbieh 2,614 feddans in 85 villages were infected and 2,613 cleared. In Kalioubieh 1,830 feddans in 152 villages were infected and cleared. In Menoufieh 29 feddans in 21 villages were infected and cleared. In Sharkieh 471 feddans in 12 villages were infected and cleared. Throughout the country 21,941 feddans in 530 villages were infected and 21,890 cleared.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LIMITED
div.p: We learn that the Egyptian Estates have paid the Egyptian Constructions Limited the sum of £11,000 in respect of an instalment due on the Savoy chambers, the huge building adjoining the Savoy Hotel, Cairo. The work on this building which was suspended during the last month, has now been resumed, and will be expedited with a view to its completion on or before the stipulated contract time.
The following work now in progress by the Constructions Company will, we are pleased to hear give highly satisfactory results :

Savoy Chambers for the Egyptian Estates. Peretti's Building, Shareh Maghraby Peretti's Building, Shareh Manakh, Anglo-Belgian Flats, Ghezireh. Dr. Garner's Villa at Meadi. Mr. Finlaison's Villa at Ghezireh. Polytechnical School at Ghezireh. Drainage Scheme at Ghezireh Reformatory, Khedivial Walda's Palace, Kasr Doubara,
and several other important works in execution by different branches of the company.
This pleasing state of affairs is due in a large measure to the able technical management of Mr. Cassinis, Chief Engineer of the Company.

Mr. D. S. Bondi, who was invested with full powers as general manager of the company at the last annual meeting, bas decentralized the working of the branch businesses and effected the reorganisation of the Company on the most economical and efficacious basis: we are most confident that this company under such conditions will give satisfactory results to the shareholders.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
FINANCIAL SCANDALS
div.p: On the 6th inst. Mr. John Robertson, asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether his attention has been called to the fact that under Article 258 of the Japanese Commercial Code, which enacts that a Foreign company which sets up a principal office in Japan, or which makes it its principal object to do business with Japan, must even though it is formed in a "Foreign country, comply with the same provisions as though it were formed in Japan, a British company, whose head office is at Hong Kong, has lately been fined at Tokio for non-compliance with the Japanese company law and whether in view of recent financial scandals in Egypt, he will recommend the Egyptian Government to adopt the above cited provision of the Japanese law.

Sir E. Grey.--As, under the existing system of Capitulations, the assent of 15 Powers is necessary before legislation applicable to a Foreign company could be enacted in Egypt, it would be impracticable to make the proposed recommendation

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in & spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: NATIVE OPINION ON THE CRISIS
div.p: To the EDITOR OF 'The "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,-Will you kindly allow me a short space in your columns, in order to contribute a few words on the present financial crisis. The oriental proverb "what is one man's meat is another man's poison" has, since the crisis paralysed commerce, been the motto of many tradesmen who persuade the natives to believe that this country is actually suffering through financial difficulties and that misery is reigning everywhere. The object of these individuals is merely, by spreading malicious rumours, to prepare the way for acquiring the wealth of Egypt with as little trouble as possible. Directly speaking there is no crisis that will hinder the financial progress of the country as long as the cotton cultivation is flourishing, and as long as the present price of cotton is secured. I declare these facts to make it known that if there is any erisis it is confined to the brokers and stockholders who often miss the mark by forgetting the old English saying "One bird in the hand is worth two in the bush." believe the time has come to direct the attention of. the Government authorities to a matter of the greatest importance, which if neglected will bring the country into poverty. The merchants I am sure are now straining every nerve to persuade the people that Egypt is destitute of money. As we are now approaching the cotton season, and as the people are in need of money to discharge their land taxation, fear is entertained that the merchants, or rather village bankers, who used to lend the farmers money, will not continue the same practice under such hard circumstances unless farmers sell them their cotton at a very cheap price, notwithstanding that the actual price of cotton varieties is published at Minet el-Bassal. The insistence of the Government to receive its taxes, and the refusal of the banks to lend money will probably aid the avarice of the greedy merchants. I therefore believe it is the duty or the Government to carefully stop the spreading about of such deceitful news and to take every means to prevent such sources of misery and melancholy that might ruin the country. . *Yours faithfully, .

div.head: EGYPTIAN SOLDIERS.
div.p: "To the Editor OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, I have noticed during the past week that the Egyptian soldiers, now encaiped near the British Rifle Club stand at Sidi Gaber, are in the habit of daily taking their bath in a state of nudity in a pool about 40 yards from the tramway line. Passengers on the trams are exposed to this indecency which I consider sufficiently obvious to have attracted the attention of the officers in command of the detachment. Hoping that the authorities will interfere.--I remain, Yours faithfully,

div.head: SUDAN WEATHER DELAYS OF TRAINS.
div.p: Bad washouts reports the "Sudan Times" of the 1st inst., have occurred on the railway 'between Zaidab and Aliab, extending over a distance of over 7 miles. The Government steamer "Dal" has been despatched to Shendi in order to transfer northbound passengers from Shendi to Zaidab, whence they will continue their journey in the Halfa express, and to bring back the south bound passengers from Zaidab to Shendi, where they will take the Khartoum North express. On account of these delays and washouts, the train due to leave Khartoum North at 9.15 last night Bist ult, has been delayed until 9 this morning. The Suakin line was washed out near Kambobsana. At least three days will be required to repair the line. No passengers for Port Sudan or Snakin were taken today. On account of interruption of telegraphic communications Reuter's telegrams were not received yesterday,

div.head: FINANCIAL DEPRESSION IN LONDON. ITS CAUSES
div.p: The all-absorbing topic of conversation, not only in financial circles but amongst people in the city generally, has been the entirely depressed condition of the Stock Markets during the last week, and especially the heavy fall in Consols and other gilt-edged securities. Never since 1848 has the premier security touched such a low figure, and everybody is naturally anxious to know the reason. No one seems to be able to state any definite canse for this condition of more than lassitude which prevails in the markets.

Several explanations are put forward, the more recent one being the serious depreciation in American Stocks, which has followed as the result of the heavy fine of over £5,000,000 imposed by the law Courts upon the Standard Oil Company. This is accepted as a sign of what is to follow in the same direction, and the expectation that similar action will be taken against other corporations is causing the public to lose confidence, with the result that one and all are desirous of realizing their stocks and shares. The question of autumn gold requirements for Egypt is again brought forward as another cause of the depression. Then again the want of confidence in the home legislation of the present Government, which is in a very large measure carried out at the instance of the Labour Party, has naturally made Capitalists very nervous. There is also a good deal of disquiet amongst the leading Railway Shareholders here owing to possible impending labour troubles and this has caused the more conservative to realise.

We have given these several reasons which have been advanced by the thinking community of the City, but in our opinion no single one of them is sufficient to cause any such decline in prices, as has been going on for some days past; but taken together however, and added to the nervousness regarding the out come of affairs in Morocco they are in our opinion sufficient to account for the present unsatisfactory state of affairs in the City.

At the moment we see no silver lining to the heavy cloud which is overhanging the financial world, and until prices reach such a level as to tempt investors to become buyers instead ot sellers, we cannot hope to see any improvement. Moreover, should the present weakness continue and the selling proceed further, there is no prophesying what may happen, as it may precipitate a monetary panic throughout the world, the consequences of which would be too serious to contemplate.

It must not be forgotten that the Premier Security is very largely held by our leading Financial Institutions, and although they have been written down from time to time, they have now reached a point when they appear a very ugly item in the balance sheets. We only mention this as being one direction in which the present decline, if it continues may be a serious blow to credit.

The "Times" in its City notes declares that the present condition is largely brought about by monetary pressure in the United States and New York's efforts to finance itself, and, as recorded above, it was an important cause of the further hardening of discount rates here ; it thus had a very direct effect on gilt-edged securities, which are always readily affected by monetary considerations, with the result that a further sharp drop in Consols jarred the already overstrained nerves of operators.

On the other hand, there appears to be no inconvenience owing to shortness of money, and the Bank of England returns, though not quite as good as they might be, certainly give no justification for the heavy depreciation which has been going on during the past few days, added to which the trade position may be described as splendid. The returns issued by the Board of Trade yesterday shew that during July our Imports increased by £3,605,505 on the very high total of July 1906, while the Exports have increased by no less than £7,000,369, these amounting to £40,452,831. In ordinary times these figures would have produced an excellent effect apon Railway Stocks, but the attack of nerves has prevented the market from obtaining any benefit from them, and the downward movement has in no way been mitigated by the above figures.
The "Ahram," has started a rumour that Sir Eldon Gorst will not remain in Egypt and that his place will be taken by Sir Vincent Corbett.
General Machacha, Minister and aide-de-camp to the King of Abyssinia, aj rived at Port Said yesterday on his way to Berlin, where he will have an interview with the Emperor William.

Fleet Surgeon C. W. Buchanan-Hamilton retired on the 26th ult. with the rank of deputy inspector general, after twenty-nine years' service. He was surgeon of the gun vessel "Beacon" throughout the Egyptian War, 1882, and was present at the bombardment of Alexandria, being awarded the medal with.clasp and bronze star. In 1884 he served with the Royal Marine battalion during the Sudan Expedition, and was surgeon at the Royal Victoria Hospital, Suakin, and of the "Sphinx" until the close of the campaign, for I which he received a clasp to his medal.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA, BUILDING BYE LAWS
div.p: In a recent issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" the tentative building regulations of the Municipality were formally advertised, together with an intimation that they had already been published in the "Journal Officiel" and that they will come into operation about the twenty fourth of August.
These advertised regulations differ but slightly from those set forth originally and which were printed as an addendum to the third article of these series.

A remark may however be made as regards the chimney regulations. Notwithstanding the present excessive heat the Municipality is mindful that the winters in Alexandria are becoming colder. Accordingly chimneys are motioned but nothing is said as to fire places.

Now, the local mason has a very crude notion of a chimney; the usual form being merely a hole cut through the wall at some suitable spot to be chosen after the building is finished. The hole being cut, a pipe of iron or zinc is fixed there to an excrescence against the wall.
In future however, these holes and pipes must have their positions settled and shown on the plans to be submitted to the Municipality together with details drawn to a scale of one tenth.

In the absence of information to the contrary we may presume that the Municipality intends simply to regularise existing practise. Nothing is said as to the formation of fire places and the size of flues. But perhaps fuller details will be given to us when the regular byelaws, to which these are as it were, heralds, are promulgated. The London Building Act has no less than 35 rules which are to be observed in the building of flues and fire places.

Let us now see what the Municipality wants by way of notice from persons intending to build in the city of Alexandria. - I. A block plan showing adjacent streets drainage ete. II. Sectional plans of each floor. Thus in a house of four storeys four plans are required. III. At least two sections--transverse and longitudinal. IV. Details of chimneys, V. Elevations at least four, one for each side. VI. Enlarged details of construction--possibly two sheets. VII. Specification about 30 pages.
All these documents are to be delivered in duplicate. This means that from ten to twenty aneets or drawings will have to be prepared and two copies of the specification.

The expense entailed will be considerable, and proprietors who are chary of employing architects at all and who, even when they do, are loath to pay reasonable fees will justly complain of this additional imposition. A client of mine is already complaining of the extra cost.

Besides this there is another grave objection to the depositing of an architects designs, details and specifications in the public archives, especially is this so when we know that in Egypt there is a pernicious custom of allowing officials, on occasion, to practise on their own account. I have met some such in consultation and have been informed by others that occasionally they can undertake commissions outside of their official duties. An undesirable and reprehensible practice.
We will now consider the various points set forth at the end of the last paper published in the "Egyptian Gazette" on July 26th and in the following order.
1. The laying out of streets and of drainage and sewerage.

In the building of a new town or the remodelling of an old one, next to the choice of site, which can only be exercised in the former case, there is nothing more important and conducive to the health and comfort of the inhabitants than wide, well-paved streets with good sewers below and efficient drainage leading thereto from the houses contiguous to the streets.

A walk, or rather, a series of darts and dodges along the narrow footway of Cherif Pacha Street during the busy hours of the day, and a walk toward the sea along one of the small streets leading to the new sea wall when the wind blows inwards, amply prove the discomfort of narrow streets and the insalubrious odours emanating from ill-arranged sewerage.

The narrowness of Cherif Pacha St eet exemplifies the narrowness and shortness of view with which, since the broad days of the Grecian street planners, our ancestors were inflicted whenever they proceeded to set out the lines of a town.
To them the immediate needs, and not even those in their fullness, were thought of. No thought was given to the inevitable increase of population and of traffic.

This want of foresight on the part of the narrow minded "fathers" of cities has cost to their posterity untold millions sterling for street widening. During the last fifty years, street and bridge improvements in London of have cost to the ratepayers a nett sum of over sixteen million (£16,246,521, or approximately £325,000 per annum.

The above figures are taken from the Report of the Royal Commission upon the means of al Locomotion and Transport in London which e contains a vast mass of evidence and information in eight stout volumes, (blue books) replete with hundreds of plans, maps and diagrams.

The inquiry of the commissioners extended for a period of over two years and embraced the exhaustive examination of the street and general traffic accommodation of London and "Greater London," covering an area of some 693 square miles (an area equal to the distance from Alexandria to Cairo and over five miles wide). It also includes an examination of the American cities of New York, Boston, Philadelphia, and Washington, and of the European cities of Vienna, Bada Pesth, Prague, Cologne, Dresden, Berlin, Brussels and Paris

A most interesting feature of the Report upon the cities abroad is the series of plans of the city of Paris dating from 1798 to 1889 showing incidentally the outgrowth of the city and the street improvements carried out in those years and especially those under the guidance of the broad-minded Prefecto the Seine, M. Hausmann.

The recorded cost of these improvements goes only as far back as the year 71, the records probably having been lost in the revolutionary fires of that year, since which time there has been spent on new streets in Paris no less a sum than £24,772,034.

Auent the Paris improvements the Com-LA missioners record the following interesting information, "It appears, that in 1798 a commission of artists laid down the various improvements which then seemed to be desirable, and these are shown on the plan No. 2."

Here surely is a good precedent for Alex andria. Let the Municipality search for a committee of artists of sufficiently broad views - avoiding always the modern expert who is often afraid of his own opinion and doubtless they will be forthcoming. Especially would a committee of this kind be of service in formulating ideas for the treatment and development of the land rei claimed and otherwise in connection with the new sea wall, and for the planning of new streets and widening of others.

The widening of Cherit Pacha Street, would be a matter well worth their consideration. If it were possible to remove the block of li buildings between Cherif Pacha and Tewfik Streets and the Boarse at one end, the Caracol at the other splendid street might result, the whole width of Mohammed Ali square leading up to an improved bifurcation of the Moharrem Bey and Port Rosetta Streets. Trees might be planted in this wi"dened street and possibly arrangements made for two lines of noiseless trams. But this, as desirable as it seems, may be too drastic an improvement, yet it cannot be gainsaid that Cherif Pacha Street is exceedingly narrow and altogether disproportionate to the amount of business carried on and the volume of traffic which passes through it.

That there is "a loss caused by want of travelling facilities" the Report to which allusion is made above, amply shows, but persons who wish to go about their business in other than the slow eastern method may judge of this for themselves.

An alternative mode of widening this street might be found by setting back the north side, but this would probably be a process equally costly and would take a longer time to settle. Many of the houses having been rebuilt, endless negotiations would have to be entered into as to compensation etc.

In London, where the greater part of the property is built on the leasehold system the widening of streets proceeds as the leases "fall in" or terminate, the lease having usually a rebuilding clause. But the process is a slow one as may be judged by the snail-like progress of the widening of the Strand and Fleet street in London.

Owing to the low-lying situation of Alexandria the relief of traffic by shallow underground tubes would be deemed to be hardly practicable, yet it would not be too difficult a task for our modern engineers to overcome. The depth of the tramway under the new King's Way is about five metres from the crown of the road to the tram rail level. It is only in the lower levels of Alexandria that water is reached before that depth.

As my space is narrow, like many of the streets of Alexandria, it is impossible that I can deal adequately with the report on the streets of London and other towns mentioned. I have called attention to its invaluable contents, containing as it does the result of the labours of a commission to which the late Sir Benjamin Baker, Sir J. Wolfe-Barry and Mr. Barclay Parsons, acted as an advisory Board of Engineers. The report should certainly be consulted by the advisors in these matters to the Municipality.
(To be continued)

div.head: THE MALTA COMMAND
div.p: Lieut.-General H.F. Grant, C.B., it is officially announced, has been appointed Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Malta, vice General Sir Charles Mansfield Clarke vacated. General Grant served in the 4th Hussars from Feb. 17, 1869, to Jan. 20, 1886, and was then promoted into the 7th Dragoon Guards, which he commanded until Marek 31, 1891. He became a major general April 1, 1900, and a lieutenant general April 21, 1906. He was Inspector General of Cavalry in India, 1898-98, Inspector General of Cavalry in the United Kingdom, 1898-1902, and lately commanded the oth Division, Southern Command, Dover. Whilst doing duty in Egypt he quelled a mutiny of Turkish soldiers serving in the Egyptian Army, and captured the mutineers in 1884, receiving for that service the brevet of lieutenant-colonel. He served in the Nile and Suakin Expeditions, 1884-85, in command of the Mounted Infantry (mentioned in despatches, medal with two clasps, Khedive's star, and C.B.).

div.head: TRADE OF EGYPT
div.p: Compared with the corresponding month last year the imports of LE. 1,892,182 during Jupe showed an increase of LE 246, 289. There are singularly few articles in the imports of which a decrease is to be noted, and, in spite of the bad times Egypt is passing through financially, it is pleasing to see a steady increase in the majority of cases.
BUILDING MATERIALS -A large increase of building wood is seen in the month's figures over last year, the figures being now LE 84,980 instead of L.E. 88,376, being now more than double.
COAL --The figures show a scarcely perceptible decrease.
COFFER. There has been a shrinkage from LE 20,000 to LE 9.000.

FURNITURE. -The total value of the imports. for the month were L.E. 41,000 against LE. 29,000 for the corresponding period last year. England now ousts Austria from the leading position with a value of LR 11,000 against LE. 8,400.

IRON AND IRON GOODB. - There has been a big increase to chronicle here, the value for June being L.E.190,000 against LE 124,000 during June last year. England just beats Belgium as the principal exporter to these shores.
LOCOMOTIVES.-The past month has seen & decrease from LE. 8,600 to LE 9,500.
MANCHESTER Goods. -Cotton fabrics were returned at a value of LE. 234,000 which is a slight drop from the similar period last year.
Marze-There has been a big drop in the maize importation figures. Whereas last year we could point to an import value of LE. 16,300 in June, we have now paltry LE. 500 in front of us
PETROLEUM.-Jane 1906 saw an import of LE. 10,000 in value. This year the same article has a value of LE 85,000.
POSTAL PACKETS --- The post office seems to be made more use as of late, the total value of the goods passing through it is LE 87,000 against L. 58,000 the previous June.
SHERP.-LE. 8,000 represented their value last June, this year it is LE 27,000.

Britain's SHARE.--The figures keep very steady and there is little scope for the pessimists or optimists to raise their voices Britain maintains her average and has just under 38% of the total trade, which compares very favourably with the 12% of Turkey, the nearest opponent.
EXPORTS.
COTTON.-Spot market showed more sigis of activity during the month and holders maintained firm prices for good qualities : the existing stock almost entirely composed of cotton over.
The premium of November contracts over July reached 1 dollar during the middle of the month, but owing to increasing demand for spot cotton the margin narrowed to 5/8 dollars at the close.

The crop reports continue satisfactory and a good supply of early cotton is expected from Upper Egypt. The Delta erop is quite as forward as usual and there is every prospect of a erop as good as last year.
(Monthly Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce).

div.head: NATIONALISATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Writers who refer to nationalisation in Egypt says a correspondent to the "Nottingham Guardian," may learn something of it from Warburton's book. "The Crescent and the Cross." I have not the book at hand, but it says that about a century ago land, agriculture, and manufactures were nationalised and managed by Government 40 or 50 years. The farmers farmed as directed by officials, and took their produce to the Government store for Government prices ; and mills for making cotton staffs, cloth, guns, sugar, &c., were worked compulsorily for Government wages, which were very low, yet not low enough to make the products so cheap or so good as those made elsewhere, and the scheme failed and ended in debts that burden Egypt still. Tens of thousands of the people were nsed up, but equality under Government and its officers Was achieved, and this is the great object of social reforms and progress, for it matters little what we suffer if all suffer alike ander universal suffrage. It is said that.

We would rather be Genteelly damned beside a duke - Than saved in vulgar company. Much more so if none at all were saved, for it is Heaven that makes bell het. It seems mistake to suppose that nationalisation of the means of production has been tried only in Egypt. A few years ago Mr. Lane and other Australians carefully formed an admirable plan for trying it, with carefully chosen settlers and plenty of capital, in a great settlement in Paraguay, and an account of its success would be more instructive than the Egyptian scheme.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché a ouvert ce matin déprimé et cette allure n'a fait que s'accentuer jusqu'à cinq minutes avant le lóture. A ce moment les haussiers, faisant un suprême effort, ont réussi a relever un peu les prix qui étaient tombés a bas. On n'en oloture pas moins a un niveau généralement inférieur à celui de la wollte. Quant aux affaires, la raréfaction va bientôt nous conduire, si cela continue, au calme plat de Juillet. Le pullulement des acheteurs at verbe haut qui encombrait la corbeille Is semaine passée et pas plus loin que lundi dernier a totalement disparu pour faire place à celui non moins encombrant des vendeurs à tout prix qui se trouvant presque seuls dans la corbeille ne peuvent opérer qu'à de rares in allées et moyennant de coûteuses conversions. C'est toujours aux réalisations de profit qu'on attribue la rómetion prósente, mais la lassitude, les positions surchargées, les mauvaises nouvelles d'Amérique, la hausse continuelle du taux d'escompte, tout cela doit bien yeting aussi pour quelque chose.

En fait de demandes, il n'y a que les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie et les Nungovich Hotels qui en aient été l'objet. Aussi leurs pour respectifs progressent-ils de 141 Å 143 et de 14 a 14 11/16. Les Nungovieh n'ont d'ailleurs pas été behangés; tout ce qu'on sait dos motif de leur reprise c'est que la demande provient du Caire

A part la Delta Light qui se consolide à 98/4 et la Daima 12 /, les valeurs dirigeantes subissent une dépréciation plus ou moins accentuée. L'Agricole revient de 8 7/82 à 8 1,8, la National Bank de 20 1/2 à 20 9,32 et Obligation Crédit Foncier de 302 1/2 à 301 l'ancienne et de 259 à 258 la nouvelle. On croit que le tirage n'a pas eu lieu hier après midi, à cause de la fête de l'Assomption; cependant les prix cotés ce matin sont entendus ox-tirage.

En baisse encore la Ramleh de 5 à 4 3/4, la Behera de 20 5/8 à 20 1/2, la Banque d'Athènes de 114 à 113, la Land Bank de 7 3/16 à 7 1/16, P Urbaine de 3 3/4 à 3 5/8, le Comptoir de 3 Ancienne et 2 31/32 la nouvelle à 2 15/16 et 2 7/8 respectivement et la Banque d'Orient de 118 à 117 vendeurs.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land recule de 2 1/16 & 1 15/16, l'United de 7,16 à 318 l'action et de 2 5/8 à 2 1/4 ls fondateur, et les Rita de 3/4 à 23, 32; les Markets sont un peu plus faibles à 29 sec, les Estates à 3/4 vendeurs, ainsi que l'Union Foncière à 4 5/8, la Levico à 15/32 sec.
Un peu mieux tenu, le Banco di Roma reprend de 104 à 105.
Sur le reste de la côte il n'y a pas de changements à signaler.
Ce sont l'Agricole, les Estates et l'United qui ont donné lieu au plus grand nombre de transactions, bien que ce nombre soit demeuré restreint.

Quoiqu'il soit difficile de prévoir ce que será notre marché la semaine prochaine, en présence surtout des éléments spéculatifs qui semblent être rentrés de nouveau dans notre corbeille en y provoquant des mouvements désordonnés de hausse et de baisse, on peut dire que les nouvelles ni l'époque ne sont guère favorables à un mouvement de hausse. Il ne faut pas perdre de vue, en effet, qu'aucune des circonstances ayant déterminé la crise n'a encore disparu.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: La direction a décidé de donner le premier grand bal d'enfants en plein air, vendredi prochain 23 août à 6 heures. En cette occasion, le Maestro Longhi préparera diverses danses, qui seront accompagnées par l'orchestre Brscale.

Demain soir, samedi, aura lieu la grande soirée de gala avec projections cinématographiques, de 10 à 11 henres, par la maison Urbangra déjà bien connue de tous les habitués du Casino. Le programme sera tout-à fait nouveau et certainement des plus amusants. Le small danone commencera de même à 10 heures.

Dimanche matin, ainsi que nous l'avons déjà annopol, aura lieu le grand concert Symphonique Saint-Saëns Massenet, comprenant l'hymne 4 Victor Hugo de Saint-Saëns exécuté pour la première fois et qui sera, nous en sommes certains d'avance un nouveau succès pour Mo Bracale et son vaillant orchestre.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de For de l'Etat Égyptien
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public, que les offres faites le 4 Juin dernier pour l'achat des douze mille vieux bidons et quatre cent cinquante tonnes de vieux bois n'avant pas été satisfaisantes, l'Administration a décidé de les remettre en adjudication. En conséquence, il sera procédé le Lundi, vingt-six Août courant, à neuf heures dn matin, à la vente aux enchères publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) des articles ci-dessus spécifiés qui se trouvent aux dits Magasins oh on peut les examiner et prendre en même temps connaissance de leurs Conditions de vente, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m., les dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.
Les Conditions de vente relatives à ces matériaux peuvent également être consultées au Bureau Central des Magasins Généraux à Bonne (Caire) aux mêmes heures que cidess.

Pour être admis à concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au préalable, verser à la Caisse de l'Administration, à titre de dépôt provisoire LE 3 pour les vieux bidons et L.E. 10 pour les vieux bois. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire les sommes jusqu'à concurrence de dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée et enlever à ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés dans un délai de quatorze jours pour les vieux bidons et quarante-cinq jours pour les vieux bois à compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre..

Les offres pourront être faites sur papier timbré de trente millièmes si l'intéressé ne peut pas assister aux enchères et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le reçu de versement du dépôt provisoire seront adressés par la poste sous pli recommandé à
Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des Chemins de fer de l'Etat à Gabbary (Alexandrie).
et sous double enveloppe, intérieure portant la suscription suivante
"Offre pour achat de vieux bidons et vieux bois"
Toute offre faite on déposée postérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Jeudi, dix neuf Septembre prochain, à midi au | plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture de brosses à peinture etc., suivant la nomenclature et les conditions du Cahier des charges relatif à cette fourniture dont un exemplaire sera mis à la disposition des intéressés sur leur demande au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary à Alexandrie et à celui de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire) contre paiement de cent millièmes.

Une série d'échantillons de la fourniture susdite sera mise également à la disposition des intéressés aux susdits Bureaux, chaque I jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure p.m., les dimanches et jours fériés exceptés, pour examen et avoir une idée des articles requis. Toutefois les soumissionnaires sont invités à envoyer des descriptions, croquis et échantillons pour des articles de meilleures qualités.

Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication devra verser, au préalable, à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration, à titre de cautionnement provisoire, une somme de Vingt-Cinq Livres Égyptiennes. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire de yra parfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence du dix pour cent du montant de L'offre agréée.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente millièmes ainsi que du reçu, constatant le versement du cautionnement provisoire susdit. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à :
Monsieur le Directeur Général des Chemins de fer de l'Etat, Le Caire.
et sous double enveloppe, intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
"Soumission pour la fourniture de Brosses à peinture etc."
Toute offre faite on déposée postérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner aucune suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve de même le droit de diviser la commande.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
div.p: The Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs Administration has the honour to inform the Public that the Kom El Akhdar Telegraph Office which belongs to the Delta Light Railways, will be opened for European correspondence from the 15th instant Cairo

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: NOTIOL. The Egyptian State Railways have the honour to inform the Public that, to avoid overcrowding of the Railway goods platforms during the Cotton Season, and the confusion necessarily resulting therefrom, the following regulations will be enforced :

"1-All consignments must be separated from one another by a minimum distance of two feet. "2-Consignments must be well arranged and stacked together. "3-When one lot of consignments has been received and stacked on one platforma no more will be allowed to be placed on that platform until there is vacant space, "le", all stacking of subsequent consignments on the top of these already existing will be prohibited, "4- A sufficient space must be left on each platform as a roadway for carts.

"Should the Railways find that these arrangements are not being carried out, and that there is confusion amongst the consignments, notice is hereby given that in such a case the gates of the station will be shut, and no more consignments will be accepted until platforms are empty, and thereafter receipt will only be given for the amount of goods for which wagons are available each day.
"The Railways invite the cooperation of the Public in carrying out these regulations, which will avert irregularities and confusion. Cairo, 15th

div.head:
KING EDWARD ON THE CONTINENT
GREAT POLITICAL EVENT

div.p: King Edward has arrived on his visit to the Emperor Francis Joseph. The two sovereigns embraced on meeting. In an interview Baron d'Aerenthal and Sir L. Hardinge stated their views on the Macedonian question. (Havas)
A huge crowd cheered King Edward : remarkable enthusiasm was evinced. (Reuter)

During the course of the dinner at the Palace King Edward and Emperor William toasted the good relations between the two peoples, and the friendship of the two sovereigns. The European press hopes that the interview will have the happiest results. (Havas)
The monarchs reviewed the troops and drove out twice. They dined at the castle King Edward left at 11.30

The speeches at the dinner were most cordial, both dwelling on the good relations existing between the two peoples. The Emperor welcomed the feelings of kinship and friendship which prompted the visit of the representative of the great British people as testifying to the good relations between the two peoples King Edward speaking in German, assured the Emperor of his great joy at the visit. "My greatest wish is that the best and pleasantest relations may exist between the two countries." He rejoiced that their Majesties would soon visit England, and he was convinced that the whole British people would receive them with the greatest joy. (Reuter)

The papers characterise the meeting between the King and the Emperor William as a great political event marking the definite turning point in Anglo-German relations, which, they emphasise, is the complement of a series of meetings and agreements testifying to the British for peace, and showing that the idea that British policy aims at German isolation is a delusion. (Reuter)
The Journal des Débats" repudiates the suggestion that France eyes the meeting at Wilhelmshoehe with askance. She regards it in the same spirit as the meetings at Swinemunde and Ischl. (Reuter)
King Edward and the Emperor Franz-Joseph had a cordial meeting. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE BELFAST RIOTS
USE OF VITRIOL

div.p: It is reported that the troops were provided on Tuesday with a quantity of vaseline as an antidote to vitriol, of which the rioters were supplied with 25 gallons. (Renter)

div.head:
TELEGRAMS.ACTIVITY OF MORENGA.
ENTERS GERMAN TERRITORY.

div.p: The famous Hottentot chief Morenga, with 400 followers, has evaded the Cape police and entered German territory. The news has been received with concern at the Colonial Office, Morenga having previously caused great trouble to the Germans. (Reuter)

The "Times," pointing out the equality of the opportunity, twice strongly emphasized the nature of the Russo-Japanese convention and expressed the hope that Japan would now take measures to remove all grounds of complaint regarding the "open door" in Manchuria and trademarks in China.(Reuter)

TThe text of the Russo Japanese Convention has been published here. Both parties undertake to mutually respect the territorial integrity and maintain the status quo and the open-door in China. (Reuter)

div.head: PROGRESS OF ESPERANTO
LANGUAGE OF HALF A MILLION
div.p: Out of the old fields springs the new corn; so out of the old languages has arisen Esperanto, a plant of some twenty years' growth, now delighting and giving intellectual sustenance to the workers in many fields of human activity,

The result of a life-study on the part of Dr. Ludovic Lazarus Zamenhof, an oculist of Warsaw, Esperanto was first explained in a book which the author published on July 21, 1887. It is now a means of intercourse between something like half a million of people
AIM AND MEANING OF ESPERANTO.

"Esperanto" is a noun derived from the present participle, active, of the verb "espert to hope, and means "the person who hopes." When Dr. Zamenhof first laid his scheme before the public he wrote under the pen name of "Dr. Esperanto." It is from this circumstance that the new language has derived its name.

Dr. Sydney Whitaker thus explains the origin of Dr. Zamenhof's life-work: "Dr. Zamenhof was born on Dec. 3, 1859, in the | little town of Bialostok, on the frontier of Russia and Germany. The inhabitants were of four different nationalities--Rassians, Poles, | Jews, and Germans-each group speaking its own language, and on bad terms with the other groups. When young Zamenhof reached his teens he grieved over this, and rightly concluded that the main cause was the misunderstanding due to diversity of language, and determined some day to invent a language | which they could all speak. At school at Bie lostock, and afterwards at Warsaw, he learned Greek, Latin, French, German, and English, which, with the Yiddish, Russian, and Polish which he already knew, equipped him well for his task. He first tried to adapt Latin, and afterwards Yiddish, for international pur. purposes, but found them unsuitable."
NOT A "UNIVERSAL LANGUAGE."

Esperanto, the outcome of twelve years' study, is not a "universal language." It is no more intended to be a rival to any other language than a wife is intended to be the rival of her husband. It is an auxiliary language, built up in the first place from those words which are already known to the greatest number of persons of average education. Thus from an ordinary page of Baperanto text an Englishman recognises 70 percent of the words, an Italian 60 per cent, a Spaniard 42 per cent, a Frenchman 80 per cent, and a German 40 per cent."

Invented as a means of enabling a comparatively small community divided in four sections by the language barrier, devoid of grammatical difficulties, and easy of acquire. ment, it has proved of immense service to men of science, business men, and travellers, and its adherents look to it to play no unimportant part in bringing about the federation of the world.

div.head: PROGRESS IN GREAT BRITAIN
div.p: "The Language," says Mr. J.M. Warden, "was introduced into Britain only a little more than font years ago, and has already made extraordinary progress. In most of the large towns centres have been formed for its study, and the British Esperanto Association which is a union of 120 of these groups, and the central organisation for the British Empire (with headquarters at 18, Arundel Street Strand, London, W.0.), is about to receive its certificate of incorporation. That Association and the corresponding French body conduct examinations and grant diplomas in Esperanto. .. Two International Esperanto congresses have already been held, at Boulogne in 1905] and Geneva [in 1906) respectively. Each was attended by about 1500 delegates from all parts of the world. On the last 00casion twenty-three different nationalities were represented." At Geneva there were held special and separate meetings of scientists, doctors, lawyers, military men, members of peace societies, Protestants, Catholics, Freemasons, Socialists, commercial men, the Press, stenographers, chess-players, and so on. Thus, while the Boulogne congress "proved to the world that Esperanto is really a language by which all people can easily understand one another," the Geneva gathering "showed that that language is practically usable in all departments of human thought and activity."

div.head: SIGNS OF GROWTH
div.p: Besides the periodical literature of various countries devoted specially to Esperanto, the "British Esperantist" being the leading monthly organ in Great Britain, many classical works have appeared in the language, while at least two scientific gazettes are published in this rapidly developing intellectual medium-the "International Science Review" and the "International Medical Review." "It is significant," I writes A. J. H., in the "Shrewsbury Chron icle," "that the Pope sent his apostolic blessing to Abbe Peltier to encourage his fervent propagation [of Esperanto) amongst the Catholics; and that universally spread union of youths, the Christian Endeavour, which has four million members, adopted Esperanto as an official language. In France it has been introduced into all the upper grade national schools, the initiative having been taken by the Town Council of Paris Moreover, the language has been placed on an equal footing with other foreign languages in the official departments of the city of Paris. In England the Chamber of Commerce in London and other towns adopted Esperanto in the programme of examinations of the commercial schools. The Minister of Education has recommended the study of Esperanto. The list of Esperanto societies affiliated to the British Esperanto Association has doubled during the year. Also in other European countries the language bas spread, particularly in Russia, Sweden, Switzerland, Belgium, Spain, &c but the progress is not so important as in France and England ... Contrary to prophecy, the Americans have become fervent adherents of the international language ... From the English Colonies, but particularly India and Australia, come excellent reports. In India now exists a national Esperantist Society, ... Japan also seems very favourable ground, the universities having given a tremendous fillip to the movement."

div.head: THE CAMBRIDGE CONGRESS.
div.p: The third International Esperanto Congress will open at Cambridge to-morrow (Saturday), when there will be short local excursions and private receptions. On the Sunday, at Great St. Mary's Church, the entire service for Anglicans will be in Esperanto. The Archbishop of Canterbury has approved of a transla. tion from the Book of Common Prayer by the Rev. J. Cyprian Rust, and a collection of twenty-five hymns. At the Church for Roman Catholics the Latin Mass will be sung as usual, but Monsignor Giambene, the Keeper of the Archives to the Sacred College of Indulgences, will come from the Vatican to deliver a sermon in Esperanto, and he will be supported by representative prelates from France, Spain, and Belgium. The Rev. W. B. Selbie, of Emmanuel Congregational Church, will also preach in Esperanto. On the Monday there will be an official reception of the honorary president, Dr. Zamenhof, by the mayor (Alderman George Stace), and an official opening of the congress in the evening at the New Theatre, where Dr. Zamenhof will als, deliver an address. On Aug. 18 the delegates will come to London.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: The Mediterranean Fleet, on the whole has done excellently according to a semi-official statement, compiled from outside sources, of the scores made by a large number of his Majesty's ships at home and abroad. The pride of place is occupied by the cruiser King Alfred, flagship of the China Squadron, and after her comes the battleship Prince of Wales, Captain H. W. Savory, flying the flag of Vice-Admiral Prince Louis of Battenberg, second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet. The Prince of Wales made the fine score of 62.98 points. Next in order of precedence comes the cruiser Venus, 60.90 points, then follow the battleship Formidable, 55.71 ; the battleship Irresistible, 51.10; the battleship Venerable, 45.01 ; the battleship Implacable, 43.19; the cruiser Bacchante, 49.45; Minerva (well known as guardship frequently at Alexandria), 39.86 , the cruiser Diana, 36.54 ; the cruiser Lancaster, 83,50 ; the cruiser Aboukir, 30.30; the cruiser Suffolk, 27.41 ; and the cruiser Barham, 25.07. The Barham, Diana, Venns, and Minerva are the organisers attached to the battle squadron, and the Aboukir, Bacchante, Lancaster and Suffolk form the Third Cruiser Squadron under Rear Admiral Sir H. D. Barry, who flies his flag on the Bacchante. The shooting of the battle squadron and the attached cruisers puts the Mediterranean Fleet in a very satisfactory position, but the Third Cruiser Squadron's performance at the target was rather poor. In fact, it stands at the foot of the list.
Major W. Bromilow, 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, has been ordered home from Alexandria to take up the duties of senior major of the 2nd Battalion, Fermoy.
Lieutenant J.W.J. Alves, King's Own Soottish Borderers, has reverted to the rank of second lieutenant at his own desire, and has joined the Indian army.

The following officers of the home battalions of the King's Royal Rifle Corps have passed for promotion to the next superior rankCaptain and Brevet Major S.F. Mott, Captains G.E.B. Hankey, C.H.N. Seymour, Lieutenants F.V. Yeats-Brown, C.D. Eyre, G.T. Blewitt, G.M. Atkinson and W.J. Davis.
The 1st Battalion Hampshire Regiment will leave Bermuda about the 17th September for South Africa, on relief by the 2nd Battalion, Cornwall Light Infantry, now at Gibraltar.

The S.S. Soudan will leave Southampton on the 13th January next with troops on board for the Mediterranean garrisons, including the 1st Battalion Green Howards for Egypt. The liner will call at Gibraltar on the 21st and at Malta on the 25th, disembarking drafts at both places, and will call at Limassol on the 29th to put one company of the Green Howards ashore there for duty in Cyrus, and the remainder of the battalion will be disembarked at Alexandria on 31st to take the place of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers ordered leave from Cairo. The Inniskillings will ship at Alexandria on the 1st February, and the company at Cyprus will be taken aboard on the return voyage, which will be made via Malta and the Rook. The Inniskillings, on arrival at Southampton on the 14th February, will be sent to the Irish capital.

For a considerable time the question of guns of larger calibre than the 12 inch one for the new Dreadnoughts has been freely discussed in naval circles, and at frequent intervals it was stated that the Admiralty was considering the construction of the larger gun. Recently it was announced that the Admiralty had at last decided on the new type of gun, and this is now confirmed by the further intelligence that several of these are in the process of building. The gun, which has a calibre of 13.5 inches, is claimed to be the most powerful one in existence, and that it is capable of sinking any battleship or cruiser afloat. The mountings of the gun will be of special construction, and the projected Dreadnoughts will be broadened to carry them it is believed. The strain produced by the concession of such a gun on firing will be extremely severe, and towards the minimising of this naval architects are turning attention. It is expected that the gun will be kept within 70 tons weight as compared with the 100 and 110 ton guns of the Admiral class of battleship. The latter were prone to droop at the muzzle, and after a hundred rounds with full charges their lives were practically over. The mention of these guns recall that there are a few of them still afloat, though the great majority have long since gone into scrap.

div.head: NEW MEDITERRANEAN COMMAND
div.byline: DUKE OF CANNAUGHTS APPOINTMENT. THE POSITION OF EGYPT
div.p: In the House of Commons last Thursday Mr. Haldane, Secretary of State for War made the important announcement that the GovernMent have decided to create a new command in the Mediterranean with headquarters at Malta. He said" I should like to take this opportunity of making an announcement as to the future arrangements for the conduct of civil | and military affairs in the Mediterranean. The King has approved of his Royal Highness the Duke of Connaught being appointed thereto las Field-Marshal Commanding-in-Chief and High Commissioner in the Mediterranean. The force under his Royal Highness's command will comprise the garrisons of Gibraltar and Malta, the detachments in Crete and Cyprus, and the British troops quartered in Egypt and the Sudan. As all matters of local military administration, except the more important cases of discipline, will continue to be disposed of by the Governors of Gibraltarand Malta and the General Officer Commanding in Egypt, his Royal Highness will be able to devote his attention to inspec tion and training, and to the consideration of questions of strategy and defence within the limits of his command. For the colonial administration of Gibraltar and Malta the respective Governors will remain solely responsible ; and similarly in Egypt and the Sudan all civil and political matters will be dealt with as heretofore by the Agent and Consul General in Egypt, to whom the Governor General of the Sudan and the Sirdar will continue to be responsible for the administrar tion of the Sudan and of the Egyptian and Sudanese Forees. In regard to questions of policy which involve military consideration, the Field-Marshal Commanding-in-Chief and High Commissioner will be consulted by the representatives of the Foreign and Colonial Offices before they lay their views on such questions before their respective departments I may add that the creation of this new command will cause no intense of expenditure. The date on which his Royal Highness will take up his command has not yet been definitely fixed.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de 20000 m. de pierre de Naples pour dallage de chaussées.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 800 (huit cents).
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressés sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 27 Août 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour Fourniture de pierre de Naples."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Généralə avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 27 Août 1907 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) DR. SCHIESS.

PUBLIC CALL-OFFICES : Cairo, Central Office, Opera Square, and New Bar; Helouan, Central Office, Maison Purvis ; Alexandria, St Mark's Buildings, Egyptian Bar, I. Castelli & Co.; Ramleh, Central Office. San Stefano Casino 30.4.906

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Goods may be booked from this company's system of nearly 1000 kilometres of line in the Delta to any stations on the Egyptian State Railways and the Helouan Line.
Public Telegraph Messages are also accepted at many stations.
For further information apply to the Company's Offices at Cairo, ALexandria, Tantah, Zagazig, Damanhour or Saida Zenab.

table.head: Helouan Branch. - Time Table from 1st May to October 1907.
